summary.text: Scalars have magnitude only (speed, distance, time). Vectors have magnitude AND direction (velocity, displacement, acceleration, force).

diagram.alt: Comparison of scalar and vector quantities
diagram.caption: Scalars vs Vectors visualization

importance.text: Direction changes everything. Moving 5m east then 5m west gives you 10m distance (scalar) but 0m displacement (vector). Speed tells you how fast; velocity tells you how fast AND where.

explanations.text: Because physics happens in 3D space. Things don't just have amounts—they point somewhere. Force without direction is meaningless.
Space has no preferred direction. Up isn't special. Every direction is equivalent, so we need to specify which way we mean.
Because change requires comparison. Motion is change in position relative to something else. Relativity demands we specify direction.
No absolute positions = must specify direction.

questions.text: Which quantity is a vector?

options.explanation: Temperature is a scalar quantity because it only has magnitude, no directional component.
Mass is a scalar quantity representing the amount of matter, with no associated direction.
Momentum is a vector quantity because it includes both magnitude (15 kg⋅m/s) and direction (east).
Kinetic energy is a scalar quantity - it represents the energy of motion without directional information.

feedback.correct: Correct! Momentum has both magnitude and direction, making it a vector.
feedback.incorrect: Think about which quantity includes direction information.
feedback.explanation: Only momentum includes a direction (east), making it a vector. All other options are scalars with magnitude only.

feedback.correct: Excellent! You correctly applied the Pythagorean theorem and found the angle.

options.explanation: Correct! This is the fundamental difference - displacement is a vector, distance is a scalar.

options.explanation: Both use the same units of length. The difference is in their nature (scalar vs vector), not units.

options.text: Displacement is the rate of change of distance
options.explanation: Velocity is the rate of change of displacement. This confuses displacement with velocity.

feedback.correct: Perfect! You understand the key distinction between scalar and vector quantities.
feedback.incorrect: Focus on which quantity has direction and which doesn't.

summary.text: For constant acceleration: velocity changes linearly with time. Start with initial velocity u, add acceleration × time.

This assumes acceleration is constant. Real acceleration varies, but we approximate with constant chunks. Calculus handles the varying case.
Because force causes acceleration (F=ma), and we're assuming constant force. Constant force → constant acceleration → linear velocity change.
Constant push = steady speed increase.

summary.text: Displacement has two parts: distance from initial velocity (ut) plus extra distance from acceleration (½at²).

importance.text: Shows why things fall in parabolas. The t² term creates the curve. Without acceleration, motion is straight (just ut).

explanations.text: Because velocity increases linearly, but distance is the accumulation of all those velocities. Integration of (u + at) gives ut + ½at².
The ½ appears because average velocity during acceleration is halfway between start and end velocities. It's the area of a triangle.
Because position is the integral of velocity, and velocity is the integral of acceleration. Each integration adds a power of t.
Distance = old speed contribution + acceleration's growing contribution.

Space and time interweave. This equation shows their deep connection—velocity change over distance is fundamental, time is secondary.
Speed² change = acceleration × distance. Energy hiding in plain sight.

summary.text: Objects keep doing what they're doing unless a net force acts. No force = no acceleration.

importance.text: Destroys the intuition that motion needs force. Motion is natural; change needs explanation.

explanations.text: Because velocity is relative. There's no universal 'stopped.' Constant velocity is indistinguishable from rest.
Space has no friction. Nothing in empty space opposes motion. Earth experience misleads—friction isn't fundamental.
Symmetry. Laws of physics are the same in all inertial frames. No frame is special, so constant velocity can't be special.
Motion is default. Force changes motion.

questions.text: A hockey puck slides across frictionless ice. Which best describes its motion?

options.text: It gradually slows down due to its inertia
options.explanation: Inertia keeps objects in motion, it doesn't slow them down. This confuses inertia with friction.
Correct! With no friction or other forces, the puck continues at constant velocity forever.

options.text: It accelerates in the direction of motion
options.explanation: Acceleration requires a force. With no forces acting, there's no acceleration.

options.text: It follows a curved path due to Earth's rotation
options.explanation: On short distances and times, Earth's rotation effects are negligible for a hockey puck.

feedback.correct: Perfect! You understand that motion continues without force.
feedback.incorrect: Remember: no net force means no change in motion.
feedback.explanation: Newton's First Law: an object in motion stays in motion unless acted upon by a net force.

questions.text: A book rests on a table. The net force on the book is zero because:

options.text: Gravity doesn't act on stationary objects
options.explanation: Gravity acts on all objects with mass, whether moving or stationary.
True but backwards reasoning. Zero acceleration is the result of zero net force, not the cause.

options.text: The normal force equals the gravitational force
options.explanation: Correct! Two equal and opposite forces (gravity down, normal up) give zero net force.
Friction acts horizontally here, not vertically. It's not why the book doesn't fall.

feedback.correct: Excellent! You identified the force balance.
feedback.incorrect: Think about all forces acting on the book vertically.
feedback.explanation: Gravity pulls down, normal force pushes up. When equal, net force = 0, so no acceleration.

questions.text: A spacecraft moves through deep space with engines off. Its motion demonstrates:

options.text: Objects naturally come to rest without force
options.explanation: This is Aristotelian thinking. Newton showed objects naturally maintain their motion.

options.text: Inertia: objects maintain their state of motion
options.explanation: Correct! This is a perfect demonstration of Newton's First Law in action.
Space is essentially empty - there's no medium to provide resistance.
In deep space, gravitational forces can be negligible. The spacecraft coasts by inertia.

feedback.correct: Right! The spacecraft demonstrates pure inertial motion.
feedback.incorrect: Consider what happens when no forces act on an object.
feedback.explanation: With no forces in deep space, the spacecraft continues at constant velocity—pure inertia.

questions.text: An object moving at constant velocity has forces acting on it.

modelAnswer.text: True. Forces CAN act on an object moving at constant velocity, but the NET force must be zero. For example, a car moving at constant velocity on a highway has driving force forward balanced by air resistance and friction backward. The forces are present but balanced.

diagram.alt: Car with balanced forces showing drive force forward and resistance forces backward
diagram.caption: Forces on car at constant velocity

questions.text: In the absence of friction, a rolling ball will eventually stop.

modelAnswer.text: False. Newton's First Law states that objects in motion stay in motion unless acted upon by a net external force. Without friction (or air resistance), there is no force to slow the ball down, so it will continue rolling indefinitely at constant velocity.

questions.text: Inertia is a force that keeps objects moving.

modelAnswer.text: False. Inertia is NOT a force. It is a property of matter that describes an object's resistance to changes in motion. Objects don't need a force to keep moving - they need a force to CHANGE their motion. This is a common misconception.

summary.text: Net force causes acceleration proportional to force, inversely proportional to mass. More force = more acceleration. More mass = less acceleration.

importance.text: THE equation of mechanics. Links cause (force) to effect (acceleration). Everything else builds on this.

explanations.text: Because force is defined as 'that which causes acceleration.' Mass is 'resistance to acceleration.' F=ma defines their relationship.
Really F=dp/dt (force = rate of momentum change). For constant mass, this becomes ma. Einstein showed mass can vary.
Symmetry again. Space is homogeneous, so momentum is conserved. Force breaks this symmetry, causing momentum change.
Force = momentum changer.

Correct! F = ma = 1200 kg × 3.0 m/s² = 3600 N
This includes gravity (mg). The question asks for net force causing acceleration, not weight.

feedback.explanation: Net force = mass × acceleration = 1200 kg × 3.0 m/s² = 3600 N

Correct! Net force = 20 - 15 = 5 N east. a = F/m = 5/5 = 1.0 m/s² east
This divides total force by mass. You need NET force, not total force.

feedback.incorrect: Find NET force first: 20 - 15 = 5 N east.
feedback.explanation: Net F = 5 N east, so a = F/m = 5/5 = 1.0 m/s² east

questions.text: Two people pull a 50 kg crate with ropes. Person A pulls with 200 N at 30° above horizontal. Person B pulls with 150 N horizontally. The crate accelerates at 2.0 m/s² horizontally. Find the friction force.
When you push a wall, the wall pushes back with equal force. These forces cancel out.

modelAnswer.text: False. While the forces are equal and opposite (Newton's Third Law), they do NOT cancel because they act on different objects. You push the wall, the wall pushes you. Forces only cancel when they act on the SAME object. This is why you can feel the wall's push—it acts on you, not on the wall.

concepts.title: Newton's Third Law (Action-Reaction)
concepts.equation: F_on A by B = -F_on B by A

summary.text: Forces come in pairs. A pushes B means B pushes A back, equal and opposite. Always. No exceptions.

importance.text: Shows forces are interactions, not properties. You can't push without being pushed. Explains rockets, walking, everything.

explanations.text: Because forces are interactions between objects. You can't interact one-way. It's like a handshake—both hands must participate.
Momentum conservation demands it. If A gains momentum, B must lose equal momentum. Forces are momentum transfer rates.
Symmetry of space again. No preferred observer means A's view and B's view are equally valid. Each sees the other pushing.
Can't touch without being touched.

questions.text: A horse pulls a cart forward. By Newton's Third Law, the cart pulls the horse backward with equal force. Why does the horse-cart system accelerate forward?

options.text: The horse's force is actually stronger
options.explanation: No, Newton's Third Law is absolute—the forces are exactly equal.

options.text: The forces act on different objects so don't cancel
options.explanation: Correct! Horse-on-cart and cart-on-horse act on different objects. Only forces on the SAME object can cancel.

options.text: The cart's force acts later in time
options.explanation: Action-reaction forces are simultaneous, not sequential.
This misses the point. The horse-cart forces are always equal regardless of friction.

feedback.correct: Excellent! You understand that action-reaction pairs act on different objects.
feedback.incorrect: Remember: forces only cancel when they act on the SAME object.
feedback.explanation: The key is the horse also pushes the ground backward, and the ground pushes the horse forward. This forward force on the horse (from ground) exceeds the backward force on the horse (from cart).

questions.text: A rocket fires exhaust gases downward. What pushes the rocket upward?

options.text: The exhaust pushes against the air
options.explanation: Rockets work in vacuum too. They don't need air to push against.

options.text: The rocket pushes the exhaust down, so exhaust pushes rocket up
options.explanation: Correct! Classic Newton's Third Law. Rocket-on-gas and gas-on-rocket are an action-reaction pair.
The gases are pushed down, not rising. Direction matters in rockets.
Pressure alone doesn't propel. It's the expelled mass that creates the reaction force.

feedback.correct: Perfect! You see the action-reaction pair clearly.
feedback.incorrect: Think about what the rocket does to the exhaust gases.
feedback.explanation: Rocket pushes exhaust down (action), exhaust pushes rocket up (reaction). Equal and opposite forces.

questions.text: When walking, you push the ground backward, and the ground pushes you forward. Without friction, walking would be impossible.

modelAnswer.text: True. Your foot pushes the ground backward (action), and the ground pushes your foot forward (reaction). This reaction force is friction. Without friction, your foot would just slip backward with no forward push from the ground. This is why walking on ice is difficult—reduced friction means reduced forward force.

summary.text: Momentum = mass × velocity. It's 'quantity of motion.' Heavy things and fast things have lots. Direction matters—it's a vector.

importance.text: The universe's accounting system. Total momentum never changes in isolated systems. THE conservation law that explains collisions.

explanations.text: Because momentum is what's conserved when objects interact. Force is momentum change rate: F = dp/dt.
Space has no special point. This symmetry (translation invariance) mathematically requires momentum conservation. Noether's theorem.
The universe doesn't track individual objects—it tracks total momentum. Momentum is more fundamental than force.
Universe keeps books. Momentum always balances.

modelAnswer.text: True. The system starts with zero momentum (stationary). No external forces act during the explosion (internal forces only). The fragments fly apart with momenta that vector-sum to zero—equal and opposite in pairs or balanced in all directions.

summary.text: Work = force × displacement × cos(angle). Only the component of force along motion does work. Perpendicular forces do zero work.

importance.text: Work is energy transfer. It's how forces change an object's energy. No work = no energy change.

explanations.text: Because only motion along the force direction 'uses up' the force. Perpendicular motion doesn't fight or help the force.
Work is force integrated along a path: W = ∫F·ds. The dot product picks out the parallel component.
Energy is the ability to do work. Work is energy in transit. They're the same quantity in different contexts.
Push along motion = energy transfer.

You feel tired because your muscles do internal work to maintain the force, but no mechanical work is done on the box. The box's energy doesn't change.

Momentum is fundamental (space symmetry). Force is its time rate of change. Impulse is the time integral—total transfer.
